properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By The Village Of Paynton
properties.Summary:
Description: A precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Village of Paynton. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individual who may access water from the Village of Paynton water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2020-01-24T14:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Paynton, 2020-01-22T13:42:00-06:00, 1B30D900-E05C-C24E-47BA-991BD9BB8AA9
Area: Village of Paynton
properties.Author: SK Paynton

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Village Of Pleasantdale
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for Village of Pleasantdale. This advisory is for the Village of Pleasantdale and for any individuals who may access water the Pleasantdale water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2020-01-30T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Pleasantdale, 2020-01-23T10:23:24-06:00, 8D503EC6-4E09-AFCC-60CC-F531686D6E6A
Area: Village of Pleasantdale
properties.Author: SK Pleasantdale

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An intense frontal system is currently crossing Vancouver Island. Heavy rain over west Vancouver Island will ease late this morning. Total rainfall accumulations of 100 mm are expected except up to 120 mm near Zeballos and Tahsis. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T03:04:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T12:56:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4167506803.2020
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog are forecast to persist until later this morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-23T19:34:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T13:43:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2806798787.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will move into the southern BC interior today bringing heavy snow to Kootenay Pass. Warm air moving into the interior will cause snow levels to rise today, and snow will change to rain over lower elevations. However, near Kootenay Pass snow is expected to continue with snowfall amounts of 20 to 25 cm expected by Friday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T04:23:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T12:24:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3484263710.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions to develop this afternoon. A series of low pressure centres moving into the Gulf of Alaska will lead to falling pressures over the southern Yukon. A disturbance will bring snow to the region beginning near midday today. With winds set to increase through the afternoon, widespread blizzard conditions are expected. Blizzard conditions will likely persist into Friday night before winds begin to ease. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T05:18:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T13:19:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3089530399.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS (January 22, 2020 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health and the Town of Smithers has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Smithers because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. For the duration of this advisory the use of woodstoves is prohibited within the Town of Smithers, unless the woodstove is the only source of heat in a dwelling. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-01-24T07:39:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-01-23T15:40:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3963104774.2020
Area: Bulkley Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. Extreme cold conditions are expected to last until Friday afternoon for parts of the eastern Kitikmeot. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T07:17:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T15:18:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4292307267.2020
Area: Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system will move into Davis Strait on Thursday evening, bringing with it strong northwest winds and blowing snow. Blizzard conditions with near-zero visibility in blowing snow are expected to begin Thursday evening and last until Friday morning, when winds are expected to abate. Visibility will improve Friday morning. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T01:04:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T09:05:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4157531084.2020
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada
